Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History Collections: Support for the AMNH Invertebrate Paleontology Collection; Addressing a critical need to conserve and digitize the Microfossil Collection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) contains one of the largest invertebrate paleontology collections in the world, estimated at 4.8 million specimen lots. This award provides funds to rehabilitate part of that collection - the Foraminifera and Ostracoda Microfossil Collection which contains unique and scientifically valuable specimens. The collection is important because of its broad range, making it possible to study the diversity of these organisms and their distribution geographically, and over geologic time. The collection is at risk due to suboptimal storage and lack of databasing. Specimens will be identified, rehoused, conserved and catalogued. Data associated with specimens will be made available to the public and researchers via the online database, along with digital images of over 1,000 specimens and CT-scan images of 50 specimens.

The improvements to this collection will enhance its utility and accessibility for researchers and students. Correctly identified and curated specimens will be used in evolutionary studies and in research in which foraminifera are used to evaluate the impacts of present and past climate change on ecosystems. Student interns supported by this grant will be trained in collection and data management and in specimen identification. Specimens will be highlighted for exhibit display and for use in AMNH's educational activities for K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The American Museum of Natural History houses an important collection of microfossils, specifically formainifera and ostracoda. These tiny fossils are important indicators of past climate conditions and therefore can help researchers interpret climate changes that the Earth is undergoing now.

The aims of this project were to improve the physical housing of the specimens to preserve them long-term, enter all the associated data into a searchable database, produce digital images and CT-scans of some of the most important specimens in the collection, and share the products of this project with scientists, educators and the public.

The collection is comprised of nearly 9,000 slides, some housing a single specimen and some housing several. The housing and conservation of these slides was a priority of the project. Slides were replaced if damaged or cracked, were housed horizontally (as opposed to vertically which was the traditional style and caused specimens to become dislodged from the slides more easily).  New labels were added to the slides and the archival boxes in which they are housed. All of these actions make it easier to locate specimens and require less handling of the slides which helps preserve the collection.

Data, such as the collection locality, taxonomic identification, date of collection and associated academic publication were entered for each specimen into a database. That database was then shared with iDigBio in an effort to broadcast the availability of the data and the specimens themselves for research.

Two and three-dimensional imaging was also an important part of this project. The structure of these specimens is only visible through a microscope and prior to this project, the only way to share what the specimens looked like was via illustration or digital photography. Over 1,400 digital images of specimens were taken during the project using a camera affixed to a microscope. Seventy-five specimens were CT scanned during the project. This last task was a particular success of the project, as to our knowledge, 3-D images of foraminifera and ostracoda had not been produced before and indeed, it proved to be quite difficult to develop techniques to produce clear 3-D images of these tiny specimens.

As a result of our innovative efforts, we were among the first to produce CT-scans of these specimens, showing the 3-D structure of the specimens, including the internal organization. The success of the 3-D scans resulted in an ability to produce 3-D printed models of the specimens, several times life-size. These models are a novel aid to teaching students about foraminifera and ostracoda.

During the course of this project, sixteen students worked as interns on all tasks associated with the project. They were trained in collection management best practices, learned how to digitally image specimens using a microscope, and gained valuable experience learning how to CT-scan specimens and to process the resulting data. Several of the students produced posters describing discoveries and innovations of the work and presented those posters at the annual meetings of the Geological Society of America.

A website describing the collection, the project, and methods and techniques used during the project was produced (http://www.amnh.org/our-research/paleontology/collections/fossil-invertebrates/microfossil-conservation-and-digitization) , as well as an intern blog (http://ipmicrofossils.blogspot.com/2013/07/foraminifera-focus-group-6-interns-1.html) where the summer interns described their work. Additionally, the AMNH produced a short film highlighting the success of the project as part of a series of films focusing on the AMNH scientific collections (http://www.amnh.org/shelf-life/episode-06-the-tiniest-fossils)
